species.name: Tetra
species.description: Small and peaceful fish that swim in schools.
species.feedingHabits: Omnivorous, enjoys small flake food or micro-pellets.
species.compatibility: Highly compatible with other peaceful fish.
species.breedingInfo: Egg layers; provide fine-leaved plants for spawning.
species.stockingRecommendations: Should be kept in groups of at least 6.

species.name: Corydoras
species.description: Bottom-dwelling fish that help keep the tank clean.
species.feedingHabits: Eats sinking pellets and leftover food.
species.tankRequirements: Soft substrate to protect sensitive barbels.
species.compatibility: Peaceful, good with other non-aggressive species.
species.breedingInfo: Egg layers; breeding can be triggered by cooler water changes.
species.stockingRecommendations: Best kept in groups of 4 or more.

plants.name: Anubias
plants.tankRequirements: Can be attached to driftwood or rocks. Low to medium light.
plants.specialConsiderations: Prone to algae growth if exposed to too much light.

equipment.name: Air Pump
equipment.description: Provides oxygen by creating bubbles that increase surface agitation, enhancing gas exchange.
equipment.importance: Ensures adequate oxygen levels in the water, especially in densely stocked tanks or tanks with limited surface area.
equipment.usage: Install the air pump with an air stone or diffuser for better oxygen distribution. Adjust the flow rate based on tank size.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Over-aeration can cause excessive water movement, which may stress certain fish species.

equipment.name: Heater
equipment.description: Maintains the aquarium water temperature within the required range for the fish species.
equipment.importance: Keeps water at a stable temperature, crucial for the health and well-being of tropical fish.
equipment.usage: Place near a water flow source for even heat distribution. Set the thermostat to the desired temperature.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Monitor temperature regularly to avoid overheating or underheating, which can stress fish.

equipment.name: Blood Worms
equipment.description: Nutritional food for fish, commonly fed to carnivorous and omnivorous species.
equipment.importance: A high-protein food source for stimulating natural hunting behaviors and improving coloration.
equipment.usage: Feed small amounts, ensuring no leftover food remains in the tank.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Overfeeding can cause water pollution. Monitor water quality.

species.name: Clownfish
species.description: Popular, colorful fish known for its symbiotic relationship with anemones.
species.feedingHabits: Omnivorous, enjoys flake food, pellets, and frozen foods.
species.tankRequirements: Requires live rock for hiding and anemone for hosting.
species.breedingInfo: Pairs can breed in captivity with the right conditions.
species.behavior: Territorial but peaceful, especially near an anemone.

species.name: Blue Tang
species.description: Bright blue, active fish known for its bold coloring.
species.tankRequirements: Needs a large tank with plenty of swimming room.
species.compatibility: Generally peaceful but can be aggressive towards other tangs.
species.behavior: Active swimmer, needs a lot of space.

equipment.name: Protein Skimmer
equipment.description: Removes organic waste from water by creating foam that captures debris and dissolved organics.
equipment.importance: Helps maintain clean water by removing dissolved organic compounds before they break down.
equipment.usage: Install in saltwater systems. Adjust foam production to match the tank’s needs and clean the collection cup regularly.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Used mostly in marine systems. Overuse may disrupt beneficial bacteria.

equipment.name: Wave Maker
equipment.description: Creates water movement to mimic natural currents, beneficial for some species and plants.
equipment.importance: Ensures even distribution of oxygen and nutrients, reducing dead spots in the tank.
equipment.usage: Place the wave maker strategically to optimize water flow without causing turbulence.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Some fish species prefer calmer water, so adjust the flow rate accordingly.

equipment.name: Heater
equipment.description: Maintains water temperature within the required range for the fish species.
equipment.importance: Stable temperature is crucial for fish health.
equipment.usage: Place near a water flow source and set the thermostat to the desired temperature.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Regular monitoring to avoid overheating or underheating.

species.name: Angelfish
species.description: Graceful, semi-aggressive cichlid with long fins.
species.feedingHabits: Omnivorous, enjoys flakes, pellets, and frozen foods.
species.tankRequirements: Tall tank with plants for shelter.
species.compatibility: Can be aggressive with smaller fish.
species.breedingInfo: Egg layers; form monogamous pairs for breeding.

species.name: Neon Tetra
species.description: Tiny, vibrant fish with iridescent blue and red stripes.
species.feedingHabits: Omnivorous, enjoys micro-pellets and small flake food.
species.compatibility: Best kept in large schools, peaceful community fish.
species.breedingInfo: Egg layers; require very soft, acidic water to breed.
species.stockingRecommendations: Best kept in groups of 6 or more.

plants.name: Anubias
plants.tankRequirements: Can be attached to driftwood or rocks. Low to medium light.
plants.specialConsiderations: Prone to algae growth if exposed to too much light.

plants.name: Java Fern
plants.tankRequirements: Grows best when attached to rocks or driftwood. Tolerates low light.
plants.specialConsiderations: Can tolerate a wide range of water conditions.

equipment.name: CO2 System
equipment.description: Provides carbon dioxide to plants for photosynthesis, promoting healthier growth.
equipment.importance: Essential for planted tanks to promote plant growth and maintain balance.
equipment.usage: Install a CO2 diffuser and adjust based on the number of plants.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Too much CO2 can harm fish. Monitor CO2 levels closely.

equipment.name: Heater
equipment.description: Maintains water temperature within the required range for the fish species.
equipment.importance: Stable temperature is crucial for fish health.
equipment.usage: Place near a water flow source and set the thermostat to the desired temperature.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Regular monitoring to avoid overheating or underheating.

equipment.name: Filter
equipment.description: Removes debris, waste, and harmful chemicals from the water, keeping it clean and healthy for fish.
equipment.importance: Maintains water quality by filtering out physical waste and converting harmful chemicals into less toxic compounds.
equipment.usage: Install in the aquarium and clean or replace filter media regularly to ensure efficient operation.
equipment.specialConsiderations: Do not over-clean or replace all filter media at once to avoid disrupting beneficial bacteria colonies.
